content.description:
“When the Natural Rights of any of our fellow-subjects are apparently at stake, every man has a right to judge for himself, and to declare his sentiments, as far as plain conclusions of reason and common-sense will fairly warrant. . . .
“. . . As all British subjects, whether in Great-Britain, Ireland, or the Colonies, are equally free by the law of Nature, they certainly are equally entitled to the same Natural Rights that are essential for their own preservation. . . .
“In every point of view, the making [of] laws for the subjects of any part of the British Empire, without their participation and assent, is INIQUITOUS,1unfair and therefore unlawful.”
Granville Sharp, British social activist, A Declaration of the People’s Natural Right to a Share in the Legislature, pamphlet originally published in London and reprinted in British American newspapers, 1774
content.question: By 1776 many British American colonists’ approach to protesting British imperial policy most differed from the approach reflected by the excerpt because the colonists

choices.label: abandoned attempts to achieve a reconciliation with Great Britain
called for sending colonial representatives to sit in the British Parliament
avoided boycotts of British goods because such tactics harmed the colonial economy
promoted the ability of colonial militias to defeat the British army by themselves

content.answer: abandoned attempts to achieve a reconciliation with Great Britain
